pullRequest.title: chore(aws-api): refactor owner-based auth unit tests
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description of changes:

Refactor AuthRule (remnant from #903)
Isolated the owner-based auth related tests from AWSApiPluginTest
Refactor test structure to allow testing for different types of auth modes
Implement FakeJWTToken generator to replace potentially sensitive actual ID tokens
Add unit tests to confirm that owner field is added correctly for OIDC usecase

move unit tests to appropriate package

I kind of think the original implementation is more readable.  What do you think?   We talked about this before here.

I think == is slightly better than ObjectsCompat.equals when comparing enums.  They both evaluate to the same thing, but == does type checking at compile time, whereas ObjectsCompat.equals doesn't do it until runtime.    Not a huge deal either way thoughn.

nodes.bodyText: I would just let this bubble up and crash the test. You can put it on the @Before and helper method signatures.

This is a little weird, where you set the apiName, but then apiName isn't used anywhere in this @Test. IF you need the apiName value elsewhere, can you pass it into a helper method, instance of relying on the instance state of the test class?
Is returning null a reasonable failure mode? Why doesn't it throw a BadAuthException or something to that effect?
Looks like it could be a for (or for-for) loop?

I think you need some helper methods to simplify all of these imperative checks.
Maybe varargs:
assertOwnerArguments(SubscriptionType.ON_DELETE,
    OwnerCreate.class, OwnerUpdate.class, OwnerDelete.class));
or:
assertOwnerArguments(OwnerUpdate.class, SubscriptionType.values());
^ Then you could use a single for-loop to go over a list of OnwerUpdate.class, OwnerDelete.class, etc.?
